entities.name: Global Scope
entities.description: The outermost scope accessible everywhere in the program

entities.name: Function Scope
entities.description: Scope created by a function, encapsulating its local variables

entities.name: Block Scope
entities.description: Scope created by curly braces with let/const

entities.name: Scope Chain
entities.description: The hierarchy of scopes checked when resolving a variable

entities.name: Lexical Scoping
entities.description: Scope determined by where code is written, not where it's executed

truths: JavaScript uses lexical scoping, where scope is determined at write-time, not run-time
Variables declared with var are function-scoped, not block-scoped
Variables declared with let and const are block-scoped
When a variable is accessed, JavaScript searches the scope chain from inner to outer
Inner scopes can access outer scope variables, but not vice versa
Each function creates its own execution context with its own scope
misconceptions: WRONG: All variables are block-scoped (only let/const are block-scoped)
WRONG: Variables are looked up where the function is called (lexical scope is where it's defined)
WRONG: Inner and outer scopes can freely access each other (only inner can access outer)
WRONG: Creating a new block with {} always creates a new scope (only with let/const)
tests: Can predict variable accessibility in nested function scopes
Can explain the difference between var and let in a for loop
Can trace how JavaScript resolves a variable through the scope chain
Can explain why a variable declared in an if block with var is accessible outside the block
